articles.title: Italian Competition Authority fines Apple EUR 98M over app tracking
articles.content: The Italian Competition Authority has issued a EUR 98M fine to Apple (AAPL) over ‘abuse of a dominant position’. The agency said, “The Authority found the App Tracking Transparency policy to restrict competition. The policy lays down the privacy rules imposed by the company on third-party developers of apps offered on the App Store. The Italian Competition Authority has imposed a 98,635,416.67 euro fine on Apple, Apple Distribution International and Apple Italia for abuse of a dominant position.

articles.title: Apple Fined $115 Million in Italy Over App Tracking Policy
articles.content: Italy’s competition watchdog fined Apple more than 98 million euros ($114.8 million), saying the company abused its dominance in the digital economy through its app-tracking transparency policy. The AGCM said Monday that Apple imposes unfair privacy rules on app developers by requiring them to gain users’ consent to collect and use data for advertising through a specific prompt. The watchdog said the prompt essentially forces app developers to ask for consent twice for the same purpose.

articles.title: Nike shares jump after Apple CEO Cook doubles stake to $6 million
articles.content: THIS VERSION HAS BEEN AMENDED TO REFLECT THE CORRECT FIGURE.Nike shares climbed about 5.5% in Wednesday morning trading after Apple CEO Tim Cook doubled his personal stake in the sportswear giant.That's according to a regulatory filing.Cook sits on Nike's board and now owns about $6 million worth of stock.The purchase appears to be a vote of confidence in the turnaround efforts of Nike CEO Elliot Hill.It comes days after the company reported weaker quarterly margins and weak sales in China.That's despite Hill's attempt to lift demand with fresh marketing plans and innovation focused on running and sports while phasing out lagging lifestyle brands.The CEO has also tried to mend ties with wholesalers like Dick's Sporting Goods... to try and put the brand in front of shoppers as competition heats up with rivals.However, Hill's plan is putting strain on Nike's margins, now in decline for over a year, and its efforts to get back on top in China are faltering.Nike's shares have slumped nearly 13% since it reported results on December 18 and are on track for the fourth straight year of declines.

articles.title: Apple announces changes to iOS in Japan
articles.content: CUPERTINO, Calif., December 18, 2025--Apple® today announced changes impacting iOS apps in Japan to comply with the Mobile Software Competition Act (MSCA). These updates create new options for developers to distribute apps on alternative app marketplaces and to process app payments for digital goods and services outside of Apple In-App Purchase. Across these changes, Apple has worked to reduce new privacy and security risks the law creates to provide users in Japan the best and safest experience

articles.title: Appeals court backs contempt finding against Apple, but reopens a door for iPhone app fees
articles.content: A federal appeals court on Thursday backed a ruling that held Apple in civil contempt for brazenly defying an order designed to open its iPhone app store to other payment systems besides its own, but the decision also reopened a door for the company to collect commission from the rival options. The unanimous decision by a three-judge panel for the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals mostly validated a scalding contempt order issued in April by U.S. District Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers for violating a key part of her September 2021 findings in a legal battle instigated by video game maker Epic Games.

articles.title: Apple takes China's smartphone battle house to house with free 3-hour iPhone delivery
articles.content: Apple customers in selected mainland Chinese cities can now get a new iPhone delivered to their door for free within three hours, as the US tech giant steps up efforts to defend its turf in the world's largest smartphone market. From Wednesday, three-hour delivery is free for in-stock items including the iPhone, iPad, Apple Watch, MacBook Pro, MacBook Air and AirPods. articles.title: Apple’s Slow AI Pace Becomes a Strength as Market Grows Weary of Spending
articles.content: Through the first six months of 2025, Apple was the second-worst performer among the Magnificent Seven tech giants, as its shares tumbled 18% through the end of June. “It is remarkable how they have kept their heads and are in control of spending, when all of their peers have gone the other direction,” said John Barr, portfolio manager of the Needham Aggressive Growth Fund, which owns Apple shares.

articles.title: Apple's chip chief reportedly 'not leaving': A closer look
articles.content: Amid a flurry of executive departures from Apple (AAPL), Apple's chip chief Johny Srouji reportedly said on Monday that he is not leaving the company anytime soon. Creative Strategies principal analyst and CEO, Ben Bajarin, joins Market Domination host Josh Lipton to discuss the reports and how consequential these executive departures could be for Apple and investors. articles.title: What Apple's executive departures mean for the iPhone maker
articles.content: Apple (AAPL) has seen several top executives depart the company recently. Some retired, such as senior vice president of hardware engineering John Ternu (who many expected would succeed Apple CEO Tim Cook), while others were poached by Meta (META), like veteran designers Alan Dye and Billy Sorrentino. Yahoo Finance Tech Editor Dan Howley outlines the details and examines what the executive changes signal about Apple. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

articles.title: Apple announces executive transitions
articles.content: CUPERTINO, Calif., December 04, 2025--Apple® today announced that Jennifer Newstead will become Apple’s general counsel on March 1, 2026, following a transition of duties from Kate Adams, who has served as Apple’s general counsel since 2017. She will join Apple as senior vice president in January, reporting to CEO Tim Cook and serving on Apple’s executive team.

articles.title: Apple unveils the winners of the 2025 App Store Awards
articles.content: CUPERTINO, Calif., December 04, 2025--Apple® today announced the winners of the 2025 App Store® Awards, recognizing 17 apps and games for their technical ingenuity and lasting cultural impact. This year’s talented group of winning developers delivered remarkable experiences that empowered users to achieve more, bring their ideas to life, and immerse themselves in stunning worlds. articles.title: Could Intel’s Apple Chip Ambitions and Malaysia Bet Redefine Its Foundry Narrative (INTC)?
articles.content: In recent days, reports have suggested that Intel could manufacture Apple’s M-series chips on its 18A process as early as 2027, alongside a planned US$208 million expansion of its packaging and testing operations in Malaysia to bolster supply resilience. Beyond the immediate headlines, the prospect of Apple as a foundry customer and the Malaysia investment both act as real-world tests of Intel’s effort to reposition itself as a competitive, globally diversified contract chip...
